text: <@U0RSTB2DB>: I agree with you. We should specify the required behaviour or outcome and not jump to the reigning terminology of the moment. The question though is, is something like Proof of Work a requirement or an implementation? is there any need to make it more generic and leave the architecture team to most likely just replace any generic questions with the accurate terminology?

There are going to be some "things" which we think need to be in the requirements sheet simply because we know they exist. I think the question there should be: can we find a justification for their presence i.e. can we find the actual requirement? and if we can't justify their presence, do we feel comfortable putting them aside for a while i.e. until their utility becomes apparent? someone mentioned yesterday the possibility of two teams, one working from use case to requirement and the other working from requirement to use case. this could be an example of starting without knowing how the requirement fits in with the user story and making sure we understand how it fits before proposing it as a requirement...
what do you guys think about use cases regarding charity/philanthropy

attachments.text: The benefits of blockchain technology are creating new operating models for many types of organizations. attachments.title: Doodle: Initial Hyperledger Identity WG
attachments.text: This doodle is to help us determine the best time for an initial phone call. Agenda for the first call is to introduce ourselves, focus on what can be a deliverable, and make a decision on how to collaborate asynchronously (slack, email list, etc.)

text: <!channel>: Please go here and vote for the days and times you are available to meet for the weekly Requirements WG meeting. Options are 7AM, 8AM and 9AM everyday except for Thursday where 7 and 8 conflict with TSC. The second yes in parenthesis means “I’d prefer not to but I will”.  You’ll need to expand all of the options to see all 13.   <http://doodle.com/poll/kmkhmudkkx2rdip9>
